PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. I refer to the minister's appearance on Meet the Press last Sunday and his passionate defence of Mr Willis's claim that the Senate should not question the minister's right to withhold documents from a Senate committee if the government decides that to do so is in the public interest. I ask: why, then, did Senator Gareth Evans tell the Senate in 1982 that any claim of executive privilege would clearly, under established law and practice, be a matter for the Senate itself to determine and, furthermore, that there is no foundation whatsoever in constitutional law or convention for any claim that the Senate has no constitutional power to require the production of documents? Is this not just another case of monumental hypocrisy? I ask the minister whether he still agrees with his own words at that time:

QUESTION.PARA: This latest obstructive stance by the Government is now ample demonstration of the fact that the Government has something to hide which the documents in question would clearly reveal.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short response to that is: what were you lot saying in government at the time? You are asking why I said what I said in 1982. The short answer is because I was in opposition. Why are you saying what you are saying now? The short answer: because you are in opposition. Why were you saying then what we are saying now? Because we are in government and you are in opposition—this is the whole point. We go through this ritual, this minuet, on all these occasions.

PARA.TAB: The basic issues are that there is such a thing as public interest grounds for refusing disclosure. There will always be a legal argument at the end of the day as to what fits in that category, and there will always be a political argument about what is appropriate to put in that category. There will always be differences in the legal analysis, depending on how the case is put, because we are all paid advocates for our respective positions and, ultimately, some of those things as a legal character can be resolved only at the end of the day in the courts. But there is also, equally, a political dimension which we all are in the business of putting and claiming for our respective sides. So do not let us have any crocodile hypocrisy coming from opposition senators on this issue. The opposition knows what the ground rules of this thing are. We know what the ground rules are—we were playing that particular game in 1982 and the opposition is playing it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With his well-known self-proclaimed reputation as a great upholder of civil liberties, as someone who admires the conventions, who aspires to the High Court if he gets the knock-back as secretary-general, is this minister seriously standing up and saying that the standards of this government have sunk so low that the government is officially prepared to concede that it lied its head off in opposition because it really did not matter, that the Australian Labor Party would say or do anything to get into government? If that is true, what has changed? Why would the Labor Party not lie and cheat in government simply to stay there? So why does the government not come clean and tell us what its real standards are? Does the Labor Party have any sense of propriety in government, or is it prepared to do anything to stay in office?

—I repeat that there are always going to be legal arguments and political arguments about the proper scope of parliamentary or executive claims to immunity from scrutiny and disclosure on public interest grounds. The inherent nature of the concept of public interest is flexible and has a flexible legal content. It remains to be determined by the High Court of Australia as to what the criteria are, because the issue has never been squarely addressed by the High Court. It remains to be dealt with on a case-by-case basis. But the arguments that are involved in this case are compelling and very easily put so far as the government is concerned. It is always a matter of case-by-case determination in all the circumstances of the particular case.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade: Relationship between Australia and the European Union

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to discussions which the minister had yesterday with his counterpart from the European Commission, Sir Leon Brittan. Given that this was the first ministerial-level meeting between Australia and the European Union since the conclusion of the Uruguay Round negotiations last December, can the minister inform the Senate of the outcome of these talks and their significance for the relationship between Australia and the European Union in the future?

—I thank Senator Devereux for actually getting around to some issues that are of practical significance to Australians, as opposed to indulgences of their interests to the Senate's. It does get to an issue that I think particularly people in the National Party would be interested in, even if the Liberals have given up on rural Australia. The Uruguay Round set a basis, due to the contribution of a number of people—not least my colleague Senator Cook—for significant potential benefits for many levels of the Australian economy, particularly the Australian rural community.
—Hey, Bob, your questioner is showing no interest.

—If he heard it, he understood it. That is the difference between him and Senator Kemp. On that basis we now have some additional assurances from the representatives of the European Union that will be of significant benefit to the Australian agricultural community. I would have thought it would be welcomed by all honourable senators. But I am pleased that at least the National Party avoids the hilarity that besets the B-graders on the other side.

PARA.TAB: There are two very important points. One is Sir Leon's confirmation that the European Union does not intend to dispose of its large agricultural stocks in a way which would disrupt world markets. Senator Boswell and others would know that there has been concern in the Australian agricultural community about the existence of those stocks and their potential to cause disruption and concern in this period leading up to the implementation of the Uruguay Round. We have been pleased that up until now the community has not been disposing of them in a disruptive way, and the assurance that it will not is welcome news for our agricultural sector.

The second point, and probably even bigger news, is the reaffirmation of what was previously known as the Andriessen-Delors assurance not to export subsidised beef to specific markets in Asia. As those markets open up they will be of extreme importance to Australia. That assurance, which was reaffirmed yesterday, means a lot to Australian beef producers and our economy. My colleague Senator Collins and I raised several other issues about agricultural products and coal. They are matters on which we will need to exert continuing pressure, not because we are seeking to reopen the Uruguay Round commitments but because we have a strong interest in the way those commitments are interpreted and implemented.

The agricultural issues that have been of such profound concern and have dominated the relationship between Australia and the European Union over the years are not over, but there is now a framework for their improvement and we have had some assurances which we welcome. The benefit is that it has enabled us to focus on some of the ongoing strengths in the relationship that have been underemphasised in the past because we have and should have focused on the profound problems in the agricultural area. We have now been able to build on that industrial and investment relationship which is extremely strong. It is possible to say that the European Union is Australia's largest economic partner. It is not our biggest trading partner—it is on the short list—but when investment is taken into account also, merchandise trade, services trade and investment, it is our largest economic partner.

We want to concentrate on those positive aspects. We signed a science and technology agreement yesterday and Senator Collins signed a bilateral wine agreement this year. So we have got significant pluses from the Uruguay Round for farmers and miners, and the assurances yesterday will build on that as a very good basis for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Health. This week the minister justified spending only 20c per woman per year on breast cancer research by pointing to his government's abysmal record on research into testicular and prostate cancer, namely an expenditure of approximately just 2c per man per year. Given that these two cancers kill approximately 5,000 Australians a year, and that his government has been in charge of medical research funding for over a decade, what does he have to say to the families of those whose quality of life may have been maximised or whose deaths may have been prevented if research funding had been at the required level over the last 11 years?

—There has been considerable argument as to what a required level is. In the last election the government promised to increase our medical research funding to two per cent, and we will be making that promise a reality or very close to it in the current budget.
—What priority can be set?

—Just a moment; if Senator Harradine hangs on, I will get to that. Senator Newman referred to the fact that 4,900 Australians are killed each year by two forms of cancer and said that it is woefully inadequate to spend what is about $1.65 million, I think, on the two in total this year. The funding for testicular—
—It is less than that.

—It is not less than that. Funding for testicular and prostate cancer is actually $500,000 over two years. Senator Newman added up the number of deaths and said that that makes it inadequate. What has to be understood is that $14 million is being spent this year on cancer research, and we do not isolate entirely each form of research into cancer as if it had no relevance to another, because it obviously does.

PARA.TAB: What really angers me about the argument, I suppose, is that we cannot simply take a relativity of deaths, look at that mortality rate and say that therefore it should get X percentage of the total budget. If I look at a disease such as MS, which does not kill people at the same rate but which causes a gradual decline in their functions and makes their life very much less a pleasure than for many of the rest of us, what do I say to those people? Do they not get any money because not enough of them die? What do I say to the asthmatics—there are only a handful? Do I say, `Look, not enough of you die, you get nothing. You can't have any money because so many die from something else.'? It is a ridiculous priority to try to put on medical research. We cannot do it.

I referred yesterday in a radio interview to a disease I had never heard of until a few days ago called Goucher's Syndrome, which affects children. It is costing almost $1 million a year to treat each one of those 40 kids in Australia who have got this very unfortunate problem. We have to work out a way of assessing them and getting enough money to them just to keep those children alive. No research has been done into that disease—nothing.

What do I say to those 40 kids? Do I say, `There aren't enough of you dying, I am sorry; we are not going to research you.'? Why do we not get around to a proper assessment of the way that we divide our research funds? I have been through the whole list of the recommendations in the Bienenstock review, which was completed some months ago. One of them is for a strategies and priorities committee to sit with the NHMRC to set some priorities which may result in breast cancer being a priority or may not; that would depend on the views of those who sit on that committee.

I have accepted that recommendation because I think it is important that we make sure that the NHMRC is in some way reflecting the priorities that Australia wants to set it. But I do not think we will ever set the priorities by measuring the deaths and then having a pro rata division of the spoils. To do that would ignore the misery of hundreds of thousands of Australians, and I will not be a part of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has just given us a disgraceful answer that only demonstrates the abysmal failure of his government over 11 years to produce a proper amount of funding for medical research in this country. I ask the minister why he is now talking about getting around to a proper assessment when his government has had 11 years to get around to a proper assessment and has had priorities for research directed to the National Health and Medical Research Council which include research into the health of the aged, women and Aborigines. If prostate and testicular cancer are not diseases of the aged, what are they? If breast cancer is not a disease of women, what is it? These have been the priority areas the minister's government nominated for several years. Why has more funding not been put into those areas? Two cents per man and 20c per woman is a national disgrace.

—I think that points out the appalling ignorance upon which this question is based. If we look at diseases of the aged, has Senator Newman heard of cardiovascular disease? It kills an awful lot more people than the diseases the honourable senator mentioned. I have not actually added up whether the pro rata basis for the numbers who die from it is good enough for Senator Newman and therefore whether the amount is good enough. I have not added that up, and I will not, for all the reasons I gave earlier.

PARA.TAB: There are many diseases of the aged that are a problem. I was discussing Alzheimer's and dementia with Minister Howe this morning with regard to the response we will have on them in the budget. We are looking at a whole range of those priorities every single day and we will continue to deliver on them. Over the course of the years of the Hawke and Keating governments, as a percentage of the budget medical research expenditure has gone from 0.37 per cent of one per cent, where it was when the opposition was in charge, to the 0.45 that it is now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism. There have been reports of increasing visitor arrivals into this country and of the hotel industry feeling the effects of economic recovery. Are these reports accurate? What are the ramifications for the tourism industry of economic recovery, especially in the area of job creation?

—Statistics from the 1993 September quarter international visitors survey show that we are attracting an increasing number of international visitors, who are staying longer and spending more. This means increased foreign exchange earnings and, most importantly, increased job opportunities for young Australians. Year-to-date figures show that international arrivals are 15 per cent higher than the same period last year, with international arrivals into Perth up 18 per cent.

PARA.TAB: While arrival increases are an important indicator of the strength of the industry, the number of nights spent in Australia by tourists and the amount of money they spend directly influences the profitability of industry and the benefits that accrue to Australia. In the September quarter 1993, the number of nights spent by international visitors in commercial accommodation increased by 23 per cent over the same period in 1992. The increase in visitor nights has been matched by a seven per cent increase in average visitor expenditure.

These improved results are reflected in new surveys of hotel business confidence by Horwath & Horwath in its Perth and Queensland hotel markets, which indicate growing confidence about hotel business prospects. Over 80 per cent of hoteliers surveyed in Perth and over 60 per cent in Queensland are now more optimistic than they were six months ago. An Ernst & Young survey of 16 four- and five-star hotels in Sydney, commissioned by the Tourism task force, shows that hoteliers expect an increase in staffing levels of between five and 20 per cent over the next 12 months. This equates to between 600 and 2,300 new jobs, which is great news for new job seekers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Yesterday the minister referred to the growth in educational exports and, quite rightly, was pleased to tell us about the industry's value of about $2 billion. He singled out the university sector as a significant beneficiary of the growth that has occurred. I ask the minister today to provide us with an indication of how much secondary colleges and business colleges contribute to the $1.2 billion earned by the education sector in 1993. Could the minister also give us a comparison with earnings for the education industry in 1988-89 in terms of university and secondary and business college sectors? Finally, what kind and level of support is now being provided by the government to the private education sector in terms of its participation in the overseas education export market?

—I appreciate the fact that Senator Bell informed me that he was going to ask a question relating to an answer that I gave in the Senate yesterday. Because question time is being held early this morning, I have not yet been able to get enough information from the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I will get that information as soon as I can. Apparently, it requires some effort to ascertain the information. At the moment the department is not able to give a precise figure of the value of private verses public institutional income based on the export earnings of education.

PARA.TAB: Apparently, a Roy Morgan survey of international students was commissioned by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. We are hopeful that will provide the information. I hope to be able to come back to Senator Bell next week with the information that he requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The minister recently announced the government's sale of the Hollywood hospital in Perth to the Ramsay Health Care group. Can the minister advise the Senate whether the final handover of the hospital has taken place yet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The official handover date of Repatriation General Hospital Hollywood to Ramsay Health Care Pty Ltd was midnight last night. On 5 December last year, I announced that the Ramsay Health Care co. was successful in tendering for the purchase of Hollywood following the state government's decision not to integrate that hospital into the state public health system. Although the changeover means the beginning of a new era for Hollywood, veterans and war widows will continue to have access to high quality treatment services.

PARA.TAB: RGH Hollywood has had a magnificent record in caring for Western Australia's veterans and war widows over the last 47 years. I cannot speak too highly of the care that the hospital staff have provided to the veteran community over that period. I am pleased that many of them have decided to stay with the hospital under its new private ownership. The manner in which veterans have been cared for has created a unique relationship between the hospital and the ex-service community. I am very confident that this relationship will now continue.

Ramsay Health Care will develop Hollywood as a 300-bed private teaching hospital and will upgrade it with a $20 million building and refurbishment program and a significant expansion of services. The successful sale of Hollywood to Ramsay Health Care means that we have achieved our two principal objectives. The first objective was to secure Hollywood's future as a top level teaching hospital while guaranteeing continuing access for veterans and war widows. The second objective was to give Western Australian veterans and war widows greater access to the local treatment they want and need as they grow older.

At the same time as the hospital is transferred, the repatriation private patient scheme will be operating in Western Australia and this will ensure that our entitled beneficiaries are able to be treated locally if they prefer. Through this scheme the government will spend $500 million over the next 10 years to purchase treatment for entitled veterans and war widows in Western Australia.

The government's contract with Ramsay Health Care clearly stipulates that the new operator, Hollywood Private Hospital, must deliver high quality treatment services for veterans and war widows in Hollywood. It must proceed with a hospital upgrading and refurbishment program. The new operator must also maintain services of special interest to the ex-service community, such as the aged and extended care department, the palliative care unit and the special psychiatric unit.

This week the Department of Veterans' Affairs posted an information package to all entitled veterans and war widows in Western Australia to help them understand the benefits that will be available to them through the repatriation private patients scheme. The Western Australian treatment monitoring committee, on which key ex-service groups are represented, will play a very crucial role in monitoring the new health care arrangements. I thank the ex-service community for the positive and supportive role they have played in bringing about the new arrangements. I also acknowledge the thorough and professional way that officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs have handled a most complex tendering process with a very good outcome for war widows and veterans in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I commend the minister on his newfound concern for Aboriginal health in the Northern Territory, 11 years after Labor took office and four years after the infamous `no child will live in poverty' deadline.
—All you have done is bag Aboriginals for your whole parliamentary career.
—Jump in the lake and read the Hansard.
—Order!
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I take it the interjection was referring to Senator Tambling. It was clearly a reflection on him, and should be withdrawn.
—I do think it is a reflection on Senator Tambling and I would ask you to withdraw, Senator Collins.
—It absolutely was a reflection on Senator Tambling, and I withdraw it.

—My question is: now that the minister has won national attention on this issue of Aboriginal health, how will he tackle the appalling state of Aboriginal health throughout Australia, or will he walk away from this promise, just as he walked away from his 1991 commitment to territorians to look at ways of stopping habitual drunks spending their social security money on alcohol?

—I really worry about the kind of person who can ask that sort of question; I really do. There is, I hope, going to be a lot more national attention given to the question of Aboriginal health. I certainly would be endeavouring to get as much of it as I could, because I do not think there is a bigger disgrace in Australia today than the state of Aboriginal health. It is an incredibly serious problem. All of us have to take some blame for that.
—Why didn't you?

—I make the point to Senator Macdonald, who interjects, that when I went to Katherine five years ago, I saw the Katherine Gorge. I did not take a trip a quarter of a mile off the highway to see people living in conditions that I described a few weeks ago as similar to those of war ravaged African nations.
—You haven't told anybody for 11 years.

—You have not been telling anybody about it; what are you talking about? What is your record? Look at the Hansard yourself, you clown. You have said nothing. I notice now it is `we', not `I'. That figures.
—Order!
—Mr President, I take a point of order. I would like your ruling on whether `clown' is acceptable parliamentary language, in light of your previous ruling.
—I do not think it is unparliamentary, but I do think it is unnecessary.

—Like a lot of other Australians, I took that opportunity to see Katherine Gorge. I did not go to see a lot of the other things because I suppose I was never fully enough aware of them as I never saw enough of them. I intend to try to make sure that Australians are made aware of them.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to spend the amount of money necessary and take the decisions necessary to make an impact on Aboriginal health status, we will have to try to take Australia with us. We will have to try to make sure that, in the lounge rooms and around the dinner tables of Australia, there is discussion of the problem. So I do intend to press this issue. I am certain that we will have a really significant announcement in the budget that will enable Australia finally to make an impact on a problem it should have been tackling not simply in the last 11 years but in the last 200 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Richardson seems to be full of emotional compassion, hope, endeavour and discussion but is absolutely short on details. Rather than just letting us rely on some significant expenditure in the budget, I would like to know about the areas, programs and priorities that the minister will pursue in this particular area. We have had significant expenditure in budgets for the last decade, and that has not achieved any result. What are the changes to the programs and the priorities that will concentrate on Aboriginal health?

—I do not think it is possible to detail prior to the budget what will happen in the budget. That detailing should happen on budget night. To give honourable senators some indication, what I would like to do is greatly expand the role of Aboriginal medical services. There ought to be a much greater number of Aboriginal health workers trained because the numbers of those are poor, and the training they have received so far has been inadequate.

PARA.TAB: We need to move some specialist services out to Aboriginal communities to give them access to a service they have never had. I have spoken to the colleges about that. There will be something in the budget for that. We will be doing things like looking to the armed services for their mobile hospitals. In many cases, we think they can be taken around to some communities that could desperately do with them. As well as all of that, there needs to be better federal coordination of the effort of all the departments because environmental health is of course the key. I hope I can supply the medicines to make people better when they are feeling sick, but if the causes of the sickness remain, of course they will keep getting sick. We have to attack both of those things at the same time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. You ruled previously that calling somebody a clown was not unparliamentary. I draw your attention to the Hansard of 9 May 1984 when the Deputy President at the time ruled that the interjection was unparliamentary. Senator Macklin was called a clown. The word was ruled unparliamentary, and had to be withdrawn.

—I am not aware of all the precedents that have been set in this house. I do not think it is a matter of such great import. I will check the Hansard record and, if that is so, I will rule it unparliamentary.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister inform the Senate of the federal government's plans to promote the International Year of the Family at the local level?

—As honourable senators would know, it is not too long since I launched the federal government's campaign theme for the International Year of the Family called `Let's look after families'. That theme particularly called on the community for participation and partnership this year for the betterment of Australian families. That partnership and participation calls on all levels of government, the business sector, trade unions, community and all sorts of organisations, particularly those at the local level.

PARA.TAB: I particularly want to highlight today the involvement of local government in the International Year of the Family. I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that a very significant partnership has been formed for the International Year of the Family between the federal government and local government through the Australian Local Government Association.

Tomorrow at the Sutherland Shire Council in Sydney I will formally announce a joint federal-local government project. This cooperative approach will be directed at tangible outcomes at the local level for Australian families. We hear a lot of criticism that nothing much will come out of IYF. Through this project, particularly at the local government level, some very real and immediate improvements for families will be able to be set up and may happen sooner rather than later.

Most honourable senators, when visiting local governments, would notice, as I have, a very big difference in the delivery of services between one council or shire and another. We are concerned about taking a cooperative approach with local government to set up models of best practice for local government in the delivery of family services and for local governments to be able to use those best practice models, or models of excellence, to assist other local councils with providing increased services and benefits to families in their local electorates. Four Australian shires will be selected to develop these models of excellence. They will include large and small shire councils in rural and metropolitan areas. Having piloted those models of excellence, the Local Government Association will distribute information relating to them to all councils and shires throughout Australia.

This is a very useful project. I notice that a number of honourable senators are interested in this answer; they know what services are provided for families at the local community level. It is interesting to note the contribution made at the local community level during the recent Sydney bushfires. It was very much a local community grassroots response, matched by local, state and federal governments. Very important also was the response that came from the Australian community generally. Some of those people had special skills, such as fire fighting and so on; but there was a tremendous response from the local community in supporting each other—family for family, person for person. It was an excellent example of what Australians can be like, particularly with support from local government.

This joint project is about assisting that process to happen, even in the absence of disasters. I am looking forward to the outcome of this very useful cooperation between local government and the federal government in the IYF.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Yesterday the minister denied that ASIS officers had been refused access to personal files. Is it not a fact that one agent's spouse was refused permission to view files held by the Inspector-General containing information and allegations made against the spouse concerned? Why did the minister mislead the Senate on this matter yesterday?

—Mr President, as I recall, the question yesterday was whether, by any direction of mine, someone had been refused access to files. That was the question; my answer was no. I had certainly seen reports about the conduct of certain of these inquiries. In at least one such inquiry—including, I think, the case the honourable senator is referring to, and this is what I said yesterday—a file had been refused disclosure initially but at a subsequent stage in the process of dealing with that particular grievance that file was handed over. The file dealt with a highly sensitive matter, and there were questions of source protection, privacy and so on involved. It was an understandable judgment made by the person in question at that stage, but it had nothing to do with me.

PARA.TAB: Really, it is a bizarre question. The honourable senator should read his Hansard before coming up with that sort of stuff again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I did read the Hansard. Yesterday the minister denied that access was prevented to the files by these people who have been complaining about ASIS. Will the minister give the Senate an assurance today that these people will get access to their files?

—Mr President, I did not deny yesterday that access was not granted. I said that access had not been denied as a result of any decision by me. I also referred specifically yesterday to a case where it had been denied. I could hardly be denying—

PARA.TAB: Senator Gibson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the whole point of my answer yesterday: I could recall one case where it had happened but it had been corrected later on. I am not going to make any undertakings about anything. These matters of dealing with grievances are presently the subject of jurisdiction by the Inspector-General for Intelligence and Security, in whom I have the utmost confidence.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that will be looked at in the course of this judicial inquiry, which I announced in principle yesterday, will be the whole system of complaint resolution and grievance procedures. If there is anything that can sensibly be done to change or improve those procedures, no doubt it will be done as a result of this inquiry. In the meantime, I am not going to plunge around in that sort of territory. It is wholly inappropriate for a minister to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Has the minister seen the reports by the Sydney Water Board detailing the massive extent of pollution of rivers, estuaries, harbours and oceans by sewage and stormwater run-off in the Sydney area? Is the minister aware that every city in Australia suffers severe environmental degradation from the increase in sewage and stormwater run-off, with Glenelg, in my own state, being labelled by the Surfrider Association as the most polluted beach in Australia? In the light of Senator Evans's reply to my question on Monday in which he said that as countries become richer they can spend more on the environment to ensure a clean environment, and in the light of the fact that Australia is a rich country, is the federal government going to adequately fund the clean-up of Australia's sewage and stormwater problems? If not, why not?

—I have seen a number of the reports to which Senator Coulter has referred, although I probably have not seen all of them. Certainly in Sydney the question of the damage done by sewage and stormwater run-off has been a pretty big issue for the last four or five years. My understanding was that the Fahey government, and the Greiner government before it, had a strategy over time to ameliorate the problem. However, there would appear to be a fair bit of evidence in recent times that that strategy has failed and that it needs to be looked at again. I do not think it would be a matter of debate between us that, in terms of constitutional responsibility on these matters, that responsibility does lie with the states. When I was environment minister, and I believe since then, it has been a matter of encouraging the states to live up fully to that responsibility. There is a varying response from the states; some do, some do not and some never will.

PARA.TAB: In terms of whether there needs to be a national plan, we first have to decide whether the states would agree to one in the first place. As honourable senators know, many states resist any sense of national involvement in these matters because they believe it cuts across their constitutional role. I will ask Mrs Kelly what stage the matter has reached at the moment, what discussions have been held, and what plans she has. It is a hell of a problem and I do hope that, nationally, we can do something to assist the states to remedy it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I remind the minister of the AAT decision in September 1993 which effectively reclassified imports of chrome split leather—the sort used in gardening gloves and industrial aprons—to duty free status. Is the minister aware of the concern this decision has caused to members of the Australian Tanners Association? Further, is he aware that before the decision was made there was no consultation with manufacturers which were gearing up to manufacture in Australia on the basis that the duty free status of chrome split leather would be maintained? Can the minister give the industry an assurance that no decision to amend the customs tariff will be made until there have been full discussions with all sectors of the leather industry?

—I have to confess that until Senator Brownhill gave me notice a few minutes ago of this question I was not aware of that particular reclassification decision. As Senator Brownhill would be aware, there are literally hundreds, if not thousands, of those decisions made every year. I do understand the importance of the tanning industry in Australia. It is an industry that is rapidly becoming world competitive. The quality of its output and its product certainly is improving and that is why we are getting exports and also import replacement in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I understand that many Australian furniture manufacturers are now using Australian sourced leather because it is of world standard and is world competitive both in price and quality. As a minister in the industry portfolio, I assure Senator Brownhill that I understand the importance of the tanning industry. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Administrative Services what implications the Hilmer committee's report on a national competition policy has for the Department of Administrative Services commercialised businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very timely question because I am hoping that the Council of Australian Governments will actually make some positive responses to Hilmer tomorrow. It is very important nationally that it does, from both the trade point of view and that of my administrative services responsibility, to which I will refer in a moment. It is a very important micro-economic reform in which I hope the states will cooperate.

PARA.TAB: That part of the Hilmer report recommendations most directly relevant to the Department of Administrative Services is that which refers to what is now called `competitive neutrality', an issue on which Senator Campbell and I have had some jousts in recent months. It is expressed in the recommendations of Hilmer in this way:

ANSWER.PARA: Government businesses should not enjoy any net competitive advantage by virtue of their ownership when competing with other businesses.

I support that principle and its corollary. That principle has been the central characteristic of the commercialisation of DAS businesses. We have had some debate here about how well we have achieved it, and that is a legitimate debate, but that it should be the objective I think is agreed.

PARA.TAB: As an aside about the DAS businesses, I should say that the Hilmer report acknowledges the productivity improvements and cost savings achieved by the DAS businesses in meeting the challenges of commercialisation, and I welcome the fact that that has occurred and has been recognised. It has been the result of a lot of diligent and difficult work by a lot of public servants, and it has gone substantially unnoticed.

The concern I want to refer to on the eve of the COAG meeting is the fact that the principle of competitive neutrality is not being applied by the states in some instances—in some instances only—in respect of either their instrumentalities competing with the Commonwealth or the Commonwealth instrumentalities having adequate opportunity to compete for state and territory work. For example, I quote the case of Australian Government Analytical Laboratories which operates on a fully commercial basis in relation to the costing and charging of its services. It competes with state-owned laboratories which are able to offer lower prices because they are subsidised by the state government. We have actually had Commonwealth tenders won by state governments because their bids were lower because they were subsidised by the states.

The states advocate that we should adopt micro-economic reform, and we should, and that we should apply competitive neutrality to our businesses, and we do—but they do not. It is very important that they start to recognise this and to address the consequences for the efficient use of public sector resources and the efficiency of the economy.

We also have the example of a territory government which has a procurement policy which specifically excludes Commonwealth government instrumentalities from tendering for work. That means that even when the Commonwealth business is the most efficient it is excluded from work simply by this policy which cuts directly across the principle of competitive neutrality.

People will get up here and make speeches about the importance of this neutrality, but they will not do it when they go back to their own states. I do not ask, within the Commonwealth or within the wider economy, for any special advantage for Commonwealth businesses, but they are entitled to compete on an equal basis. If people think the competitive neutrality principle is not being properly implemented, let us have that debate, as we have. I think it is. But it is very important that the state governments be prepared to give to those Commonwealth instrumentalities that same opportunity for competitive neutrality. I hope that will flow from the Hilmer report adoption by COAG tomorrow, which is so important.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The government certainly recognises the significant contribution Australian merchant mariners have made to the defence of Australia. World War II Australian merchant mariners are covered for war injuries under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act. War injuries are defined to restrict the scope of compensable conditions essentially to those conditions which can be shown to be directly related or due to enemy action. Claims under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act are determined on the civil standard of proof, that is, on the balance of probabilities.

PARA.TAB: In January 1989, my predecessor as Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Ben Humphreys, asked the then Deputy President of the Repatriation Commission, Ms Jocelyn McGirr, to report on the needs of Australian mariners, Commonwealth and Allied veterans and Allied mariners. Ms McGirr's report was released in October 1989. Australian merchant mariners are already eligible for service pensions under the Veterans' Entitlements Act and disability pensions under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act.

In the 1991-92 and 1992-93 budgets, the government acted on a number of the major recommendations in the McGirr report. Treatment benefits available to Australian merchant mariners were considerably extended and Australian merchant mariners were given access to compensation arrangements which provided a sum of $10,000 to any Australian merchant mariner who was illegally detained in Nazi concentration camps during World War II.

I am surprised that Senator MacGibbon is not aware that the question of benefits available to Australian merchant mariners is one of the terms of reference for the Baume review committee, which is currently looking at a range of issues involved in the compensation program of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. That committee, chaired by the Hon. Peter Baume, who is well known to many coalition senators in this place, will be reporting to me by 18 March 1994. At that time, the recommendations of that report will be examined by the government in the context of the next budget. One of the issues that will be reported upon is the issue raised by Senator MacGibbon in his question today.

There is very little more I can say, or am willing to say, to Senator MacGibbon, apart from the fact that it will be addressed in a budget context. Of course I have made myself aware of the resolution of the House of Representatives and the arguments in support of that resolution that were so effectively mounted by the honourable member for Shortland, Mr Peter Morris, and other members of the House of Representatives.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council: Funding

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health, and it follows an answer that the minister gave earlier today. Is it a fact that the minister is saying that priorities for National Health and Medical Research Council funding should be considered by another body which is responsive to the views of the public? How will the parliament be involved in that? Can the minister tell the Senate whether he agrees that the National Health and Medical Research Council should spend public moneys on supporting experiments which require the aborted foetal subjects to be as fresh as possible, with adequately developed organs? The fact is that such experiments; that is, grafts into patients with diabetes, have been singularly unsuccessful. Would the minister examine that as well, and identify to the Senate how these issues are going to be dealt with in response to public fears?

—I gave an indication earlier that, as part of the response to the Bienenstock review of the National Health and Medical Research Council, Bienenstock recommended a committee, which he called SHARP, which is about health and research priorities. I have accepted that recommendation. That committee therefore will be set up later in the year. But I have to respond formally, and before I do that I intend to discuss with the National Health and Medical Research Council the exact details of that—and who should be on it.

PARA.TAB: If it is to reflect priorities—which is a broad term, and therefore needs some input from a source other than the strict research community—then it is going to be a matter of determining the kinds of people who ought to be on it. I have not done that yet, but I will discuss that with the National Health and Medical Research Council first, and I will present a formal response to that review. I intend to do that here in the parliament so that the honourable senator and others with an interest in the area can form an opinion before we take any action.

In terms of any particular research which the NHMRC has funded, I would have to check on the matter and get a response. As the honourable senator would be aware, not every bit of research is going to be successful. There are failures in the research community. That is a matter of fact. That is why so much money is always spent in developing any cure or improvement, because researchers will follow up on as many leads as they can. Some will lead nowhere but, just occasionally, one leads to the right place.

So there are failures, and I cannot ever administer a program under the NHMRC where we do not have them. That is an inevitability. All we can do is hope that the standard of those who are allocating the grants is so high that they do not make mistakes. In the end they recommend those grants to me. I am yet to refuse one. I am not aware of predecessors refusing them either, because the group in NHMRC is impressive, and when they come up with recommendations—experts examining research programs to determine how good they are—then I think it is difficult for politicians to start refusing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I accept the point that was made by Senator Richardson about whether experiments are successful. But precisely what right has the NHMRC got, being a science-driven organisation, to examine major issues which are involved in this question that I have raised? Those major issues involve the reliance of experiments on the deliberate abortion of foetal subjects, the inability of the subjects to grant consent to the utilisation of their organs for donor purposes, questions of brain death determinants and sentience, the nature and timing of interventions likely to occur on the aborted foetal subjects in the course of harvesting transplantable organs, and the social consequences of those procedures, including the implications for other incompetent human subjects manifesting features which differ from the norm. How does the minister say that the National Health and Medical Research Council, which is a research group, is capable of determining those issues?

—I will have to get an answer for Senator Harradine on the specifics of his question, because I do not have one. I will go and do that. But I guess if one is going to say that the National Health and Medical Research Council should not have any role in determining whether or not that kind of research would be proceeded with, then one has to wonder what we do with the medical profession at large, because the National Health and Medical Research Council is largely made up of pretty eminent people from the profession.
—You should spend more on research.

—I have already said we are going to announce the largest increase in research spending since federation on budget day, and I will proceed to do that. There is a dilemma in trying to determine those questions. It is very hard to understand how to cut the profession out. I will get a fuller answer tomorrow.

Senator Richardson's defence was couched in the terms of the interjection he made to me across the chamber. He said to me that the speech and the points that I made on Tuesday about breast cancer did not get a line's reporting from the press gallery because he checked. What an appalling way to measure the value of women's lives in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is we had a dorothy dix question to Senator Crowley on the year of the family and we were made to hear feel-good statements about collectives, not about individuals. I said on Tuesday that I knew women who had died of the disease and that I now have another friend who was just diagnosed and is about to become very active in making other people aware of the fact that for 11 years this government has done nothing.

As I said, we had an answer to a question on the year of the family—a dorothy dixer—which said absolutely nothing. Many of those women who are dying of breast cancer are mothers with quite small children. If the government needs something to justify finding additional money to spend, surely the year of the family can provide such a reason.

On Tuesday I said that the way in which the government prioritised its spending has caused great anger. I pointed out that in the so-called health benefits for women statement published in the budget papers the government has provided $51 million in the name of AIDS education for women, trying to place upon them a guilt in respect of being able to prevent the disease. According to the government's own documentation, only 127 women have had the disease. The point is that there is valid reason to give research for AIDS funding but there are also enormous calls for proper funding to be made available for women who are dying of breast cancer. No improvement has been made in more than 20 years. Senator Richardson rose and said what a good job the government is doing and that there is no case to answer because the speech I made did not get a line in the press—that is, we are to measure the success or failure of human lives by his collectivist tag. The government stitches up deals with groups, and to hell with individuals. The concern on this side of the Senate is with every individual Australian woman who contracts the disease. The treatment has not been improved because the research has not been done. Mammography has been introduced, but it does not treat the disease. There are plenty of examples of women who have to get in line to get the treatment.

Senator Herron's speech on Tuesday outlined, with great precision, the neglect and the cynicism that this government, in office for 11 years, has shown in this area. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

priority for AIDS programs . . .

PARA.TAB: This government has a proud record in women's health promotion. It should be remembered we developed a federal-state women's health program. It is not in their Fightback documents; it is not in any of Senator Bishop's public speeches—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh yes, it is!
—I have certainly not heard her speak of it in this place.

—We have just heard a diatribe from Senator Reynolds, who put her finger on the real problem just as she was completing her speech when she mentioned women's health promotion. —I did withdraw it. I substituted `witches'.

—I withdraw unconditionally. PARA.TAB: The people of Australia recognise that this government has had 11 years to do something about setting priorities and putting more money into the bucket for medical research. Do we tell them that we are using the criteria suggested by those opposite for the allocation of research money? That is heartless and ridiculous.

PARA.TAB: The opposition should be reminded that it was going to cut $8 billion from health outlays. It was not going to spend any more money on aged care so, presumably, there would be no further research in that area. It was going to cut veterans affairs spending by $8 billion. It was going to make total savings to its budget of $40 billion. I would be very sensitive about this matter if I were a member of the opposition because its cold, heartless and cruel attitude to the allocation of research funding is appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `harridan' would not even enter my mind when considering the diatribe just delivered on the other side. I would not have the temerity of accusing anybody on the other side of being a harridan, even after the sort of behaviour we have just witnessed.

PARA.TAB: Senator Reynolds said that we were grandstanding. The greatest grandstander in this parliament is the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson)—every week, a disease a week. He started on the AIDS bandwagon. Now he is off the AIDS bandwagon. Then we saw him on the front page of the Australian walking around with an Aboriginal lady and saying that he was going to cure Aboriginal health problems; he got one tap turned on for one Aboriginal tribe and was on the front page of the Australian. I have already told him that I have got the statistics on Aboriginal health for when this government came to power 11 years ago. What has happened since then? In the 11 years since this government came to power Aboriginal infant mortality has increased and Aboriginal health has deteriorated. The real answer to the Aboriginal health problem is to educate the Aboriginals in relation to their own care.

I will be reminding the minister of his promises, year by year, if we are all still here—and hopefully we will be in government. The latest thing is breast cancer and he is on the breast cancer bandwagon. The coalition has put forward proposals on breast cancer research in a bipartisan fashion, but suddenly it has become a political football. It should not be a political football. We should not be hearing this screaming diatribe from the other side about what we might or might not have done—

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the screaming diatribe from your side?

—I would tell Senator Zakharov that it is a bipartisan approach that we are pursuing. I take Senator Richardson's example. He said today that the reason he does these things in relation to Aboriginal health is to highlight Aboriginal health so that the community as a whole appreciates the problem and so that it will discuss the problem, and out of that we will get community support. I agree with him totally. That is what we are trying to do in relation to breast cancer research. The reality is that the government allocates $1.2 million for breast cancer research and $750,000 of that goes to one institute in New South Wales. That $1.2 million would not even run Senator Richardson's personal staff, his department, his salary or his travel. Yet that is the amount of money that is spent on breast cancer research in Australia. It is a national disgrace. We are trying to bring attention to it so that that amount of money will be increased.

PARA.TAB: The reality of breast cancer is absolutely tragic. Forty per cent of women who get breast cancer die of it; that is half the population of this country. The incidence at the moment is one in 12. Lady senators here—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the rate overseas?

—The overseas rate is much the same, depending on which country one is in. Senator West knows that we heard about Korea where the incidence of the disease affects women between the ages of 35 and 45—a distinct difference to our own population. As Senator Newman said, there are young women in this country who get breast cancer, and young children and families who are affected by that. It is not a political football, and it is a disgrace that it has become one. It should not be; it affects all of us. There is an increasing incidence of breast cancer in this country; it has increased by 20 per cent in New South Wales in the last 10 years. In America breast cancer affects one in 10 and the figure is going down to one in nine with the ageing population; there is nothing magic about this.

PARA.TAB: I was appalled at Senator West casting aspersions on the treatment of breast cancer in this country. We are world standard. In many respects we are leading the world in relation to the lesser surgery that is done. I instanced the other day the shortage of radiotherapy departments and equipment in this country to handle this disease. I say to those opposite: do not make this matter a political football; it is not a political football. It is far more important than that. Those opposite should not denigrate themselves by trying to attack us about something that we were talking about 10 or 11 years ago, before they came to government. It is a national disgrace. I applaud Senator Richardson in his aim to increase the amount of money being spent on medical research. Only 25 per cent of applications for research to the NHMRC succeed, and the paltry sum is a disgrace. It is a disgrace that those opposite have not increased the amount in the 11 years they have been in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a very brief comment to correct a couple of things said by honourable senators opposite. I do not think it was intentional, but Senator Herron said that 40 per cent of breast cancer sufferers die from it, and in the next sentence said that we were talking about half the population. I do not think he was intending to link those two figures; obviously, not half the population get breast cancer.
—Half the population are women.

—Half the population are women. I wanted to make sure that the record did not imply that half the population were at risk. Also, reference was made to figures showing that the rate was not dropping. I point out that this is the pattern all over the world, not just in Australia. That again is a function of the ageing of the population. With most diseases that strike people later in life, the incidence is not dropping because the population is ageing; we are living longer. When women's life expectancy was in the forties, obviously a much lesser proportion died of breast cancer. With women's life expectancy now nearing the eighties, obviously the incidence will rise.

But that excludes any surviving Djugan people, and they say that they are the traditional custodians of this land.

PARA.TAB: What the minister said in a very high-handed manner was, `I will just assume that the Yawuru people are the claimants in this instance, I will set up a mediation process which recognises them only, and we will take it from there'. I am querying whether the minister made sufficient inquiry before he issued this declaration. I challenge the minister to show that he did carry out such inquiry. I put it to the Senate that he did not. We will have a fiasco, with continuing uncertainty over the development of the Broome Crocodile Farm and with any chance the Djugan people might have had being ruled out. TALK.START.PARA: —Could I therefore suggest that Senator Loosley seek leave to move a further motion to take note of the President's statement, and we will grant leave.
