TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement made by the President this day.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to delay the Senate unduly as I know estimates committees are looming and they are of particular importance. But I do want to make some remarks about the President's statement earlier today and some of the issues that Senator Alston raised.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston seems peculiarly sensitive about the article that I wrote in the Sunday Telegraph last weekend. I could perhaps understand why he might be sensitive on the issues that I canvassed and why others might be sensitive because what that article sought to do from my personal perspective as an ALP senator—and the article was clearly marked, Stephen Loosley ALP senator—was to expose the grotesque way in which the committee on the print media has been operating and to draw certain parallels with other committees that operated in other jurisdictions, particularly in the United States.

I used terms such as `witch-hunt' very deliberately because that was the direction in which the committee, to my mind, appeared to be going and still appears to be going. It also exposed the manner, to an extent, in which the committee has been operating. We have seen over the past several weeks a gross lack of consultation within the committee framework. The government has been deliberately excluded from decision making on the committee itself, even though there are four government senators sitting on the body, and even though at times very useful contributions have been made by the government on issues such as how best to look at cross-media ownership.

When people wanted to wave subpoenas around and begin threatening gaol terms, the government senators suggested we simply communicate, for example, with Minister Michael Lee, and ask for a briefing. The briefing was forthcoming. We suggested on another occasion, for example, a private meeting with Treasurer Willis to try to sort out some of the contentious matters. That option, for example, was never taken up. Again, it was falling back on the notion of legal advice, subpoenas and threatening gaol. All of those issues were canvassed in the article.

The suggestion has been made that perhaps it should have been stated very clearly at the bottom of the article or across the top of the article that I was a member of the committee. But no-one need be in any doubt about my position. For heaven's sake, over the past several weeks, in concert with my colleagues Senator Sherry, Senator Murphy and Senator Carr, every Labor member of the committee has been continually identified in the mass media, whether it be ABC television, commercial television, SBS, the Sydney Morning Herald, the Australian, the Canberra Times or any other number of mass media outlets. No-one need be in any doubt about my position.

No-one also need be in any doubt that I used any material that was either sensitive or confidential to the committee in preparing that article. Everything that I used was a matter of public record, whether in Australia or in the United States. I did not seek to be a casual observer. I did not seek to be objective. I sought to argue a position. It was a elementary matter of free speech. And on this committee, continually, issues arise of free speech, basic civil liberties and fundamental human rights.

I am very pleased to be numbered amongst those people, with Senator Murphy, Senator Sherry and Senator Carr, who continually defend the fundamental rights of Australians against the encroachments of those who would seek arbitrarily to wave subpoenas at people, to threaten people with gaol or to intimidate witnesses before the committee. This is a very important issue, not only in the immediate framework of the year 1994 but for the long-term future.

I do not apologise for one word in that article. I do not resile from anything which I wrote. I am proud to have made that contribution. I am very pleased that it stung a number of people opposite. One can always tell when something has hit home when one's opponents complain loudly about it. Every word in that article, from my position and, I believe, from the position of the government, is an accurate reflection of what has been happening or what has happened on other occasions in other jurisdictions.

The point that I made fundamentally was that, as of 1857, the American congress had legislated away its power to prosecutors, when there were rulings of the court that the congress could only gaol people until the congress rose, until the session ended. By 1857 congress reasoned that this power should be given away to the judiciary. It voluntarily legislated it away. I could have added, of course, something which emerged in the hearings in Sydney—and Senator Carr and Senator Sherry will remember this, when we had Mr Mulholland before us, for example—that as of 1971 the United States house of representatives decided it would not even contest anymore people's right to plead the first amendment in refusing to hand over documents. That is not even contested by the United States house of representatives.

Yet here we are in 1994 threatening people with gaol, incarceration, imprisonment—dusting off the cells downstairs! My view is that the power ought to be legislated away by this parliament, by the House and the Senate and given to prosecutors. Contempt findings may certainly be made but the power to prosecute, the power to incarcerate, the power to imprison ought to go off to where it should be, with the judiciary, under separation of powers under the Australian Constitution. That, basically, is what we will arrive at at the end of the day when this committee is operating.

Senator Alston has said to me both privately and publicly, has said to my colleagues, `Assume goodwill'. This morning he began to approach matters from the point of view of consultation. We will see how that works. If he has changed his view, if he has changed his perspective, if he has changed his approach, we will see if that works. It has not worked to date because it has not been tried.

We have seen things come into the chamber that have never been before the committee. Senator Carr tells me that, as of 8.20 last night, AAP had the details of a meeting that was still in progress. We have been faced with constant leaking of things to the media from informed sources on the committee—not the government, because we have not been part of the play. We have not been part of the loop of information. We have been excluded from the processes of deliberation and decision making. Things have been organised behind closed doors. There has been no openness; there has been no transparency—none whatsoever. I hope that will change.

I am saying to Senator Alston as chairman of the committee now: we are prepared to take him on his merits; we are prepared to test that view. Senator Alston is accusing me of, alternatively, contempt for process, of unethical behaviour, of impropriety. I will not level those charges against Senator Alston, although a number of my colleagues might be minded to. Let me just say that, as the chairman to date, Senator Alston has not distinguished himself. I hope that changes.

When we write the minority report on this committee, it will be about ethics and propriety. It will be about courtesies that ought to be observed on Senate committees. It ought to be about the manner in which Senate committees ought to operate. As chair of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances or the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I never walked into this chamber without having consulted the committee and had a committee decision below the basis on which I was operating and moving proposals in the chamber. I have not done that and I am unaware of anyone on the government side who has ever done that. Perhaps we might debate that later on. But if we are ever to achieve any results, there has to be a capacity on the part of the committee to involve everyone and to take contributions from everybody on the committee. It cannot be selective and it cannot be a deliberate policy of isolating a minority on the committee in order to achieve straight five-four votes all the time, as we have seen to date on this committee. A characteristic of this committee is that inevitably there have been majority decisions on the contentious issues. That really ought to change.

I will say more about these matters in future articles that I intend to write on the workings of the committee. I hope those articles have exactly the same impact that the original piece has had today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The President ruled that there was no conflict of interest under the quoted standing order and, strictly, according to his explanation that is true. But we are not here today debating whether Senator Alston is a good chairman of this committee. We are debating whether by selectively misleading, by omission of a vital fact, Senator Loosley misled people who read his column. I believe that he did.

PARA.TAB: I believe that it is absolutely pertinent to the interpretation of that article that Senator Loosley identified his membership of that committee. I am referring, of course, to the power that has been cited far too often during the sittings of the Senate print media committee. He says, `This seems to have escaped much of the coalition which dominates the committee in strong alliance with the Democrats'. All he needed to say was,`And, as a government member of this committee, I object to that' or, `As a government member of this committee, I have a different view' or, `As a government member of this committee. . . whatever'.

I think all members of the committee enjoy benefits from being a member of that committee—benefits of access to information; of access to legal opinions. Senator Loosley is entitled to his opinion. All I am saying—and I say this about any newspaper column—is that readers are entitled to transparency. They are entitled to read the article and make a connection if they wish. It is not enough simply to say, `Senator Loosley is an ALP senator'.

The critical fact is that he is an ALP senator representing the government on that committee. He is expressing views, expressions of interest—whatever. He is seeking to be objective in making his comments on the matters on which he is speaking, but he cannot be, as a member of that committee.

It is not a matter simply of editorial policy. Senator Loosley is the one who introduced the notion of ethics into this debate. It is not a matter of people being stung. It is a matter of the ethical behaviour of a person who is a member of this place and who has the opportunity to use a newspaper column. He should adhere to basic standards. A basic standard should be that he identifies that he is a member of that committee, because that one fact is probably the most pertinent fact that ought to be included in that article. He is guaranteed newspaper space. I believe he has some obligations as a result of that.

Nobody can oblige him to present the facts honestly. Mention was made yesterday about the inaccuracy of Senator Loosley's view of what congress has or has not done. Additionally, as he wants to get into the facts that have not been mentioned in here, it is his government which passed the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, which put in place the sanctions.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wasn't here then.

—Senator Loosley was an influential member of the Labor Party in New South Wales in 1987. If he wanted to have a say, he could have. This is another fact which has been selectively omitted. All he had to say was, `This was put in place by a Labor government in 1987. I do not like it, and I think the parliament should rescind it'.
—I just said that then.

—But Senator Loosley has not said it in the article. He has implied the very opposite; that it is everybody else's fault that these powers exist and may be tested, and it has nothing to do with the Labor Party nor, indirectly, with him.
—Can we see your next newspaper article as subeditors?

—Certainly. Senator Loosley also said that nobody need be in any doubt about his position; he is so unbelievably well-known throughout Australia that everybody would see `Stephen Loosley, ALP Senator' and know everything he stands for. The starting point should be that a person comes fresh to an article, and is entitled to read that article, make the connection between the author's position and the article, and come to whatever conclusion he or she sees fit, based on the facts that are in this article. That is the whole point. The whole point about Senator Alston's question to the President is whether he behaved appropriately in not disclosing his committee membership.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that Senator Loosley did not. It would have been very simple to say, `I am making these expressions of opinion from the perspective of a government member of this committee'. That is the most pertinent fact. Irrespective of what the honourable senator thinks about sanctions and the actions of the United States Congress, the most pertinent fact that readers are entitled to know is that Senator Loosley is not simply an ALP senator, but a government member of that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has indicated that there is no conflict of interest in terms of Senator Loosley writing an article for the Sunday Telegraph on 20 February. In that article he argued cogently and forcefully that the behaviour of some members of the Senate in establishing committees such as this inevitably leads to a miscarriage of justice, in that individuals are persecuted and, potentially—as has been seen in historical cases—their careers and lives are destroyed. He also indicated that the right of this Senate to gaol people was one that he did not support, and that he would like to see some changes in the legislation and the way in which these matters are dealt with by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: It was perfectly proper for Senator Loosley to put a point of view about his position regarding what are fundamental questions in this country about the rights of citizens and their relationship to their parliament. It is perfectly proper for him to be able to say, as a member of this parliament, that this is not an appropriate use of this place. That, in essence, is what has happened here. It is not proper for the Senate to be used to dragoon and abuse the citizens of this country by threatening them with gaol and, as Senator Loosley has indicated, attempting to intimidate and coerce people, in order to force a political agenda through this place—which clearly has happened with the establishment of this committee.

What is apparent is that this is an inevitable consequence of the establishment of committees such as this. It is not designed primarily to deal with substantial issues of public policy, but as a political stunt—a political agenda—by certain members of this place to attempt to prosecute their political claims and political views about actions that have taken place.

It was abundantly clear from the examination of the terms of reference that were forced through this place that this committee has been established with the premeditated view that a political agenda should be prosecuted using the powers of this Senate. As Senator Loosley has indicated quite clearly, that is a view that members of the government do not share.

Senator Kernot indicates that we should have transparency of action, and I agree. There should be transparency of action of all senators in this place. The threat to intimidate people, gaol them, and drag public servants before the Bar of this place should be exposed. The public should understand exactly what is involved. We should be clear about what people are intending to do with the citizens of this country.

We talk about public accountability. What about the public accountability of senators to treat the citizens of this country with a measure of respect; to be able to explain to people what senators are trying to achieve? The transparency works both ways. Honourable senators opposite have to be clear and make sure that they are publicly accountable for their actions. There should be no apology for this. If they are so right in what they are doing, they should explain themselves. We are quite clear that we intend to explain to the public exactly what is involved with the abuse of the powers that have been proposed in this matter. Public interest immunity does not mean that anybody can refuse to cooperate with the Senate, but we are saying that the right to gaol people has to be challenged very seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't tell people that it is your government's bill; that is the relevant point.

—Of course Senator Kernot talks about my government. It is quite apparent that the legislation, in terms of the privileges matter, was brought through this place and is a product of discussion from within this place. Is the honourable senator saying that she did not vote for it? Is she saying that she did not support it? That is a lot of nonsense. Is the honourable senator saying that it was not a product of the discussion within this chamber? Of course she is not. There is a political agenda.

PARA.TAB: What we see here are the standing orders, which in essence come down to standing order 5(4); that is, five votes against four votes. This is what this committee is all about. Five votes of those opposite against our four votes; and those votes are going to be used to abuse the power that they perceive we, as a Senate, have. The basic standards that they talk about in effect mean that the rights of citizens in this country will be trampled upon in the pursuit of their political agendas. Those opposite want to abuse and intimidate—and attempt to score a political point about the operations of this parliament.

We are talking about the substantive issue—and that is what I am interested in—of foreign ownership in this country. There are plenty of opportunities in this place for senators to discuss the substantive question of who owns what and why. But that is not the question. We have not heard anyone from the conservative benches in this chamber talk about the substantive issue because the policy of the conservatives on this matter is that foreigners can own whatever they like. Those opposite do not believe in putting restrictions on foreign ownership.

This government has a position on foreign ownership and it is rightly subject to public debate. The question has to be: what is the position of the conservatives? The terms of reference as indicated by this chamber suggest to me that that should be the matter that is under review. That is clearly not what is under review. What has been under review is the rights of public servants and the freedoms of public servants in terms of their civil liberties and their capacity to resist the overbearing abuse of power by members in this chamber.

We have indicated that there is some concern about the right of Senator Loosley to have his say. That is a concern that we have. We have our say publicly because this committee is not functioning to allow the members of the Labor Party to have their say. It is quite apparent that the operations of this committee are fundamentally flawed. What we are seeing is the committee's abuse of not only the citizens of this country, but also the procedures of this place. The terms of reference were established to allow that to happen. The chairman is able to make statements on behalf of the committee. The problem is that statements are being made on behalf of the chairman, which is fair enough, but it should be clear that that is what they are—the chairman's statements, not necessarily the committee's statements.

At 20 past eight last night I picked up the AAP wire service and I read that the request for confidentiality before the committee would not always be met. Senator Alston told the AAP that requests for confidentiality would not necessarily be accepted in relation to all documents. That is not a decision of the committee. I cannot recall any resolution to that effect of the committee. But Senator Alston indicated publicly at 20 past eight last night, according to the AAP wire service, that that is what the position would be. That is fair enough, it may well turn out to be the case, but it is not appropriate for the chairman to announce unilaterally the position of the committee without a resolution of the committee.

Standing order 5(4) is not the appropriate way to run this place, and that is essentially what is going on. That is what our complaint is. Senator Loosley is correct when he says that he has nothing to apologise for. He has a right to put a view about his attitudes before the people of this country. Day in, day out, our positions have been explained with regard to all the mass media of this country. Senator Murphy, Senator Loosley, Senator Sherry and I have been quoted directly on our views. It is preposterous to suggest that there is any conflict of interest. The position of the President in that matter is entirely appropriate and completely justified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I go to the heart of Senator Loosley's defence to what we are debating today and that is whether he should have disclosed the fact that he was a member of that committee when he wrote that article, for which I presume he was handsomely paid. His defence was essentially this: `I am such a well known public figure that anyone reading that article would immediately say, "That's Stephen Loosley who is a member of the print media committee".'
—Rubbish.

—That was his defence. That is the way he put it. He said, `Anyone who reads the newspapers, anyone who watches television, knows that I am on that committee and so is Senator Murphy, Senator Sherry and Senator Carr'. This is a matter of public notoriety, if you like—
—It is.

—Senator Sherry is confirming my point. What follows from that is that he does not need to tell the punters that he is a member of that committee because the minute they pick up and read an article by Senator Stephen Loosley they immediately say to themselves, `That's the bloke on the print media committee'.
—It doesn't matter.

—Precisely. Senator Sherry is making the point. That is a preposterous suggestion. That article is there to influence public opinion and to have casual and not so casual observers read it, ingest its contents and be persuaded by it. To the extent that they read it and it purports to express views on the way in which committee systems operate or how disgraceful it is that people can still be put in goal in the 20th century, I would have thought it is a very relevant matter to know that the writer of the article is heavily and intimately involved in the whole political debate that goes on in that committee. Senator Sherry might like to think that that committee is not having much of an impact, but that is somewhat contradicted by—
—It is having an impact.

—It is? Okay. That is interesting. It is very important to remember how we come to this point of considering whether or not sanctions ought to be applied. Senators will remember what Senator Gareth Evans had to say this morning in question time. I do not think he is notorious, but perhaps a future article of Senator Loosley's might like to reflect on this. In the final report of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege—
—Are we here to debate the sanction or not?

—Just a moment. In the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege, of which Senator Evans was the deputy chairman, a number of these matters were canvassed, in particular, whether or not the right of ultimate sanction should remain a matter for the parliament as opposed to being transferred to the courts—which I think is what Senator Loosley is now arguing. What that committee said in chapter six was:

SPEECH.PARA: A House is not confined to breaches of undoubted privilege such as those conferred by Article 9 of the Bill of Rights. It is the ultimate arbiter of what constitutes contempt and is bound neither by the courts nor by precedent . . . It is easy enough, by concentrating on serious matters, to pick out actions which may be held to be contempts of Parliament.
One of those was disobedience of the lawful directions of parliament or its committees.
It continues:

If, as we think should be the case, imprisonment is to be maintained as an ultimate sanction against those who commit serious breaches of privilege or other serious contempts of parliament, we have decided that the jurisdiction should remain with parliament.

Here we have a committee that over a period of years seriously considered all of these issues and rejected what Senator Loosley is putting. In other words, this government, with Senator Evans intimately involved in that whole process—because he actually moved amendments which tightened it in many respects—made a decision that it was proper for the committee to retain the powers it had to compel the disclosure of documents and the ultimate sanction of fine or imprisonment.

PARA.TAB: In those circumstances, I would have thought Senator Loosley, as Senator Kernot rightly pointed out, should at least have the political courage to say, `This is the government's position. It has never been queried to date but in the context of this committee I am now suddenly objecting to it. I have not until now objected to this but a committee has been set up on which we happen not to have the numbers'. I am sure those opposite are acutely aware of the power of numbers; that is how they come to be in government in the lower house. There happens to be a second chamber and, whether they like it or not, that chamber also operates by the power of numbers. A committee is able to be set up and, for once, those opposite do not have the numbers on the committee.

That is not a licence for us to ride roughshod over those opposite and it is not our intention to do so. But let me take the opportunity to explain why it was that notice of a motion was given in the parliament yesterday—and I thought those opposite would have understood the reasons advanced elsewhere for that fact. It was in no way an attempt to predetermine what the committee would do. It was simply to safeguard the position of the Senate because, unless that had happened, it would have been too late to have given the notice today for the matter to have then come on on Monday, by which time the committee's original motion would have bound us to adhere to an earlier date and we would not have been able to take evidence from a whole range of witnesses, whom Senator Loosley concedes are a necessary part of the inquiry. So let us not be precious about all that.

As I understand the position of those opposite, they do not really object to that extension of time; they object to the manner in which it came about. I have said to them and I will say it publicly that it is my intention to consult at every opportunity, to the extent that a note was circulated to them that they thought did not allow the full opportunity to consult, so I will do my very best to make sure that we improve on that situation in the future.

What Senator Carr was talking about was not a briefing—I am looking at an AAP print-out—and was in no way canvassing what the committee might have decided or would decide in the future. It was simply stating facts which I would have thought are very much on the record. Indeed, it has been pointed out to me that I have been quoted as saying that this would be an option for the committee. That is in no way canvassing what was discussed. As I am sure all senators would appreciate, we have only to look at the standing orders of the parliament to see that the Senate is given clear powers, that public servants are required to cooperate, that documents must be produced when requested, and that it is a matter for the Senate to make these decisions.

Senator Loosley can argue as much as he likes—it is a matter of political contest—that somehow he has this right to claim executive privilege and that no-one should go behind it. It just happens that he is flying in the face of all the conventions, all the judicial decisions over the last 20 years and all that Senator Gareth Evans said in the Senate in 1982. Senator Loosley ought to at least acknowledge all that and acknowledge that he is flying in the face of what is on the public record. Therefore, it is proper for me in the circumstances to make that fact known. If the media wants to know what are the rules of the game, I am entitled to point out to them what the standing orders say, what the terms of reference of the committee say, and what is contained in the Parliamentary Privileges Act. They are all matters of record.

If Senator Loosley wants to disagree with the merits of them, if he wants to foreshadow amendments, fine, he can do it. But there can be no argument, surely, with me stating propositions about what is disclosable, what witnesses are compellable and what procedures ought to be followed. He can argue the toss if he likes.

Finally, to get back to the substance of the argument, I would hope that in future when Senator Loosley writes these paid contributions he will at least acknowledge that he is not such a figure of public notoriety and not so worldwide famous that we can reasonably expect every person who reads the article immediately to say, `That's him. That's that Senator Loosley on the print media committee. I can put all this in context. I know where he is coming from'. There might just be someone with a little less intelligence, or someone who did not happen to be paying attention when he was out there on the box one night, who might think that he was making a statement just as an ALP senator—someone who did not have an interest in the proceedings, someone who, between 1987 and the present time, has not absolutely accepted the provisions of that act. I would be very interested if he would like to tell us in a future article where he has ever quarrelled with all those propositions until now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quarrel with the abuse of power by people like you.
—There is no issue of abuse of power. The government's act gives the power.
—That is the central issue.

—Let us be clear on this because it is very important. Let us talk about abuse of power. I do not quarrel for a moment with the proposition that a Senate committee has to exercise its powers very carefully, and that if it acts arbitrarily or capriciously—
—You have threatened all and sundry with subpoenas and gaol.
—Just a moment.
—There is a list of people. You can read it in the papers every day.

—That is not the fact. As Senator Loosley well knows, all that Senator Kernot did was point to the contents of the government's own Parliamentary Privileges Act which says in its final section that those who do not cooperate and produce documents are exposed to a range of penalties which, as I have pointed out, Senator Evans carefully thought about between 1982 and 1987 and finally he put in place an act which recognised the necessity to retain those powers.

PARA.TAB: Senator Loosley can argue, and I will be in heated agreement with him, that that does not give us the right to kick a head whenever we see it. We have to act responsibly and we have to act sensibly. To the extent that we do not, it will be a matter of public debate and public backlash. That is a completely separate argument to saying that somehow it is outrageous and improper to even contemplate in the 20th century that parliamentary committees should have these powers.

Senator Loosley should have the guts to admit that his government thought about it, put those powers in place, and has never, until this committee arose, quarrelled with the proposition. Let us read next time that he is actually intimately involved in this committee. He has his political barrow to push. He may keep pushing it, but he should let us know where he is coming from.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Migration Act 1958 as amended by the Migration Reform Act 1992. The reforms effected by both the Migration Reform Act and this bill are to commence on 1 September 1994. The bill also provides for consequential technical amendments to other Commonwealth legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Migration Reform Act 1992 makes important changes to the Migration Act 1958. It seeks to simplify the legal basis for administration of entry to and stay in Australia. It expands merits review by the Migration Internal Review Office and the Immigration Review Tribunal, and modifies appeal rights to the courts. It also establishes a detailed code of procedures for the processing of visa applications and reviews and clarifies the procedures in relation to cancellation of visas.

The commencement of those parts of the Migration Reform Act 1992 that were originally to commence on 1 November 1992 was deferred to 1 September 1994 by the Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1993. A major reason for seeking deferment, as I advised honourable senators at the time, was to allow for the making of a number of amendments, mainly of a technical nature, to ensure that the legislation operates smoothly. The bill now before the Senate contains the amendments which I foreshadowed last year.

All the changes provided for in the bill are consistent with the principles and scheme of the Migration Reform Act, as enunciated by the former Minister. Most are of a technical nature, correcting drafting errors, ensuring consistency of language or, in some instances, rewriting provisions to achieve the same outcome with greater clarity.
The remainder of the amendments will ensure that particular migration matters are administered in a way consistent with the scheme of the Migration Reform Act previously passed by Parliament.

For example, one of the key objectives of the reforms is to clarify the status of all non-citizens in Australia. In simple terms, a non-citizen in Australia will be required to have a visa to be lawful. A non-citizen who does not hold a valid visa must be detained and is then subject to removal from Australia.

Grant of a bridging visa will provide a non-citizen, who would otherwise be subject to detention and removal, with lawful status for a limited period. The bill provides for more than one class of bridging visa. This reflects the fact that bridging visas will serve a number of different purposes and will be granted on the basis of a number of different sets of criteria. The detail of the bridging visa scheme will be contained in regulations.

The creation of a class of visas to be called special purpose visas clarifies the status of persons currently exempt from the requirement to hold an entry permit to enter and remain in Australia. Currently the Migration Act exempts from this requirement a variety of non-citizens, including representatives of foreign governments and their families, heads of State, military personnel from other countries engaged in military exercises, ship and airline crew in Australia for a brief period, and New Zealand citizens who present a valid New Zealand passport on entry. This exemption will not apply under the reforms as it is inconsistent with the principle that lawful status flows only from holding a visa.

Special purpose visas will provide lawful status for non-citizens who are presently exempt non-citizens other than New Zealand citizens, and will be held when, and for as long as, a non-citizen continues to be present in Australia for a specified purpose. These visas will not be subject to the usual provisions relating to visas such as the need for an application, the need for an administrative grant of the visa, and the need for the grant to be evidenced. This reflects the fact that many of the non-citizens who will be holders of these visas enter Australia in a manner that makes it impractical for the usual administrative procedures to apply; for example, foreign military personnel engaged in joint military exercises.

New Zealand citizens will be granted special category visas at the border on presentation of a valid New Zealand passport. Given that they arrive in Australia in the normal way it is appropriate that normal administrative processes requiring an application, grant and the issuing of evidence of grant, apply.

Another amendment which is intended to clarify the status of non-citizens in Australia is the creation of a new class of visa to be known as an ex-citizen visa. This amendment will provide that, while in Australia, a person who loses their Australian citizenship, for example by acquiring the citizenship of another country, will be taken to be the holder of visa entitling them to remain in Australia indefinitely. This visa will be subject to the same cancellation provisions as any other permanent visa. Creation of this new class will avoid the situation where such persons could automatically become unlawful non-citizens, subject to mandatory detention and removal.

Other areas where the bill provides for minor amendments are in regard to the procedures for considering visa applications and cancellations, clearance of arrivals at the border and in regard to review.

Visa application procedures are to be amended to ensure that applicants can effectively nominate a representative to receive communications from the Department and to ensure that applicants are given a greater opportunity to comment on adverse information about them which they may not previously have seen. The procedure for cancelling visas, where incorrect information has been provided, is refined in the bill to ensure that a visa holder has the opportunity to both show that incorrect information has not been given and, if the decision-maker concludes that incorrect information has been given by the applicant, show that there are mitigating reasons why the visa should not be cancelled.

The bill refines provisions relating to the clearance of arrivals at the border to ensure the smooth processing of both citizens and non-citizens. For example, provision is made for the clearance of a person that a clearance officer knows or reasonably believes is an Australian citizen, even though the person may not have documentary evidence of their citizenship. There are also amendments to ensure that a consistent approach can be taken to all persons who arrive in Australia without a visa.

The bill ensures that particular decisions that are currently reviewable on their merits remain amenable to review after 1 September 1994. These include decisions refusing close family visitor visas and resident return visas where the applicant is overseas, as well as review of points assessments where an application is put into a pool. Proposed amendments also enable expedited review of bridging visa decisions where the applicant is in detention.

In order to provide for smoother implementation of the legislation it is proposed that the Migration Act 1958, as amended by the Reform Act, be renumbered. The insertion of a large number of new provisions into the Migration Act means that, without renumbering, awkward references to provisions such as section 26ZEA will result. The renumbering of the Migration Act will take effect on 1 September 1994.

The bill also provides for consequential amendments to other Commonwealth Acts, largely reflecting changes in terminology, such as the substitution of the term "entry permit" with "visa", and the creation of the special category visa for New Zealand citizens in Australia.

Since the decision was made to defer the commencement of the Reform Act there has been considerable activity within my Department in preparation for implementation of the proposed changes. As well as the identification of necessary amendments to the Reform Act and other related legislation, significant progress has been made towards the drafting of subordinate legislation, the preparation of procedural instructions, and the revision of computer systems and data bases. In addition, a strategy has been developed for the provision of information and training to target groups, both inside and outside the Department.

It is essential for the successful implementation of the changes contained in the Reform Act that many of these activities are completed well in advance of the 1 September 1994 commencement date. In particular, I would note that the Act itself, the regulations and procedures, and appropriate forms need to be finalised, printed and distributed to all officers well before the commencement date so that they can become familiar with the reforms and be able to provide an effective and high quality service from the first day. Members of the public, including clients and registered migration agents, also need time to become familiar with the reforms.

While much of the preparatory work is being done concurrently with the consideration by Parliament of this bill, none of these matters essential for effective implementation can be finalised until the amending legislation is settled by Parliament. It is therefore vital that the bill passes through both Houses of Parliament by early May.
I commend the bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 28 of 1993-94—Efficiency Audit—Department of Veterans' Affairs—Use of Private Hospitals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has before it an efficiency audit report into the use of private hospitals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In 1915 the first of the repatriation acts was passed in Australia to look after those who enlisted in the First World War. From that time onwards there has been an expanding range of benefits available for those who have served this country in the armed services in time of war. One of the benefits has been the provision of hospital care for veterans. That has been administered through what has been known as the repatriation general hospitals, which have been sited in all the capital cities—Greenslopes in Brisbane, Concord in Sydney, Heidelberg in Melbourne, Daw Park in Adelaide, Hollywood in Perth and a similar hospital in Hobart.

PARA.TAB: Some years ago the government decided to sell the repatriation general hospitals and incorporate those into the health services of the various states and, where that could not be done, to sell them to private authorities. At the same time, they introduced the RPPHS, the repatriation private patient health scheme. That scheme allowed veterans to have access, under certain conditions, to intermediate level health care in private hospitals.

Health care is very important to veterans. This report points out that 70 per cent of the treatment population, that is, the veteran population, will be 75 years or older by the year 2002. Hospital admissions for this group are expected to double by that time. That is because the great bulk of veterans presently are veterans of the Second World War. There is a tidal wave going through, and the demand by veterans for health care is increasing.

This audit report assesses the treatment veterans are getting from private hospitals under the RPPHS. It makes 29 recommendations. Dealing with those recommendations briefly and in sequence, the first is for a standard approach be made between the states, which is a commonsense approach. There is a recommendation that there be a review of the indemnity provisions so that the Department of Veterans' Affairs is better protected against claims arising from treatment; that multi-year contracts be entered into where possible with private health care providers; that there be a national approach where possible; and that there be reasonably equal input from both the administrative and medical staff in negotiating these agreements.

In all public services in Australia there has been a tendency to believe that there is such a perfect animal as a manager who knows everything about everything, and that it really does not matter what he is managing; if he has management skills, he can manage, and manage brilliantly.There are many shortcomings with that proposition, and as the Auditor-General reports, it is important that the medical staff have an equal say in the arrangements being made to guarantee there is decent and adequate treatment for the patients.

The basic approach of the audit office is to set up the best commercial practice for all the arrangements that are entered into. We are looking at something that will run to well over $100 million a year in the provision of treatment.

Further, there are recommendations about standard assessments and methods of treatment. There is quite a bit about how payment should be audited—that there should be standard charging procedures, and a way of assessing charges in a fair and accurate way. There is also a recommendation that the DVA should pay rapidly for the treatment so that accounts can be checked at or close to the time of treatment being delivered in order that any anomalies can be picked up. The ANAO overlooks the fact that rapidity of payment is also very important for the providers of treatment. Those running private hospitals need their bills to be paid rapidly because they have to pay their accounts within 30 days, or whatever the terms are, and often the government forgets people are in a bind for ready money.

At the end of the day, the report can be summarised in terms of saying that it stresses the need for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to make sure care is available when required for veterans; that high quality care is available and that it is delivered. Those are the two undertakings the government entered into with the veterans community when it moved down the path of getting rid of the repatriation general hospitals. Many veterans were very concerned about that because they thought their special access to high quality health care through the repatriation general hospitals could be diluted or become of a lesser standard if the hospitals went into the state health services. The government went out of its way to give undertakings that high quality health care and access to that care would be readily available, which is re-enforced by the Auditor-General.

Procedures are also recommended by the Auditor-General to improve the accounting system, making it more accurate and accountable, because there are quite large sums involved here. Of course, ultimately, the obligation is on this parliament. We are the inheritors of those promises made many years ago in the early days of the First World War to look after the veterans who served this country. It is quite proper that the Auditor-General, being an officer of the parliament, not of the government, should bring this matter before the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to a couple of comments made by Senator MacGibbon and also, briefly, to the report of the Australian National Audit Office on private hospital usage. The report outlines that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has made considerable progress in establishing private hospital arrangements as an important backup to the public hospital system under the repatriation private patient scheme. Over 200 contracts around Australia have been put in place since 1991.

PARA.TAB: The report notes that my department has approached the audit from a positive stance and provided detailed and comprehensive responses to the audit office throughout the 12-month process. My department stressed to the audit office that private hospital negotiations are at a transitional stage.

The effect of integration or privatisation of the repatriation general hospitals has a significant impact on the use of public, as well as private, hospitals as each repatriation general hospital is either integrated or sold. Even after integration, there is a heavy emphasis on public hospital usage, which is the first level of care made available under the repatriation private patient scheme.

The availability of private hospitals and their role in providing services for veterans vary widely across the states. The vast majority of the Australian National Audit Office recommendations have been acted upon or considered for future development. For example, the standard contract is currently being refined, and where appropriate contracts are being extended beyond the single year term.

The Australian National Audit Office has highlighted potential savings of $4 million from the negotiation process and $3 million from contract administration. These so-called savings have been discussed at length with the audit office. The estimate of $4 million was based on an estimate of savings against one health insurance fund in one state. My department has had some problems with that methodology. The insurance fund concerned is not a major fund in that state, and a comparison against other health funds shows that my department has already made significant savings.

The department does agree further savings can be made through the establishment of preferred provider arrangements and expansion of volume discount arrangements. Opportunities for savings of this nature have been limited to date due to the uncertainty surrounding service levels required in various regions following integration. They will only be expanded to full potential after the expiry of the transition periods following the introduction in each state, when public and private sectors will be competing for departmental business on a case mix basis.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs acknowledges the difficulties with processing of private hospital payments to ensure their accuracy, particularly that the correct discounted rate is paid.Systems are now in place to overcome the majority of these concerns, and other improvements are in the pipeline.The savings of $3 million in contractor administration are based on errors noted in 1992-93, before the use of my department's private hospital validation system. This order of errors will not recur under the new system. The department is preparing a comprehensive private hospital strategy which will provide major directions for both the short and longer terms. This strategy does take into account the recommendations that have been made by the Australian National Audit Office.

Finally, private hospital negotiations are proceeding well. Following the audit, my department is taking steps to ensure that more cost-effective use is made of computer modelling to assess private hospital usage and private hospital demand. My department will continue to ensure that veterans have suitable access to high quality services in private hospitals, where they are needed and required.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week, on 22 February, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a speech at the Australian National University, entitled `Reshaping Australian institutions', in which he dealt with a range of issues. He claimed that, over the last 10 years, the government had gone a long way in reshaping some of the basic institutions in Australia. One to which he referred was the relationship between the Commonwealth and the states. He outlined four principles on which he believed institutional change would occur that would lead to `a much more cooperative relationship developing between the Commonwealth and the states'.

PARA.TAB: The speech has attracted a considerable degree of media attention, most of it favourable. It is the four principles the Prime Minister mentioned as underpinning his approach to Commonwealth-state relations that I wish to address briefly. I believe the press reporting of the speech has been quite distorted and that, far from ushering in a new era in Commonwealth-state relations which could be described as important institutional change, quite the opposite is the case. The government and the Prime Minister have failed totally to address the main aspect of change required in Commonwealth-state relations, which has always been acknowledged to be the Commonwealth-state financial relationship. That issue has not been addressed at all. Indeed, it has been specifically set aside by the Prime Minister.
The Prime Minister mentioned four principles for Commonwealth-state relations. Let us look at each of them. The first so-called principle he outlined states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we recognise that the States have a vital role as units of Government in Australia, because there is this debate, which you often see from time to time, about abolishing the States.

In other words, the first great new principle is that we are going to recognise the existence and the role of the states. What an extraordinary statement to list as a basic principle that is going to usher in a new era of institutional change. The whole basis of our nation is contained in the constitution. The essence of the constitution is the federal relationship between the Commonwealth and the states and the existence of the states themselves. It is pretty big of the Prime Minister to accept Australia's constitutional arrangements. It is great that our Prime Minister has now come to recognise that we have a constitution in which are enshrined the role and existence of the states.

PARA.TAB: I suppose it is a bit of a move forward because he and his party, the Labor Party, have always been antagonistic towards the states. They have sought progressively, and successfully, to reduce the role of the states in Australian government. It goes back many years. In terms of this Labor government, it started with the Franklin Dam dispute in 1983, when there was a total usurping of the role of the states in relation to the environmental issues associated with the Franklin Dam. At that time, and ever since then, this government has sought increasingly to encroach on, if not outright override, state jurisdiction.

I well recall—I am sure other senators would as well—Mr Keating's famous speech in October 1991, which he used as one of the springboards for his successful coup that saw him usurp the prime ministership from Mr Hawke a couple of months later. In that speech on Commonwealth-state relations and federal issues, the then aspirant to the prime ministerial throne, Mr Keating, pronounced:

SPEECH.PARA: I admired Gough Whitlam for his unhesitating drive, in enhancing the powers of the Commonwealth.

That always has been, still is and, I am sure, will continue to be the agenda of the Prime Minister. So it is not only incredible that he has raised that as a first principle; it is also hypocritical in the extreme that he is now pretending that he and his government will ever do more than pay lip service to that principle. The second principle the Prime Minister outlined states:

. . . both the Commonwealth and the States should independently assess the value of reforms and use them for their own sake, not as part of a deal in which the Commonwealth is supposed to buy the cooperation of the States.

In other words, he is saying that there should be an independent assessment of reforms for the benefit of the states rather than relying on Commonwealth financial inducement. That is pretty rich, coming from a Prime Minister who sought to override the most fundamental reforms to industrial relations in my own state of Victoria and in Western Australia. Those reforms would have been of undoubted benefit to those states, particularly Victoria, in attracting investment, but they were thwarted in one of the greatest grabs for central power by Labor and the trade union movement that we have seen in this country. So much for the second principle that the Prime Minister enunciated. One could say much more about it. The third principle he enunciated states:

. . . that we are willing to enter into a genuine discussion between heads of Government and portfolio Ministers to look at the present roles and responsibilities of the States and the Commonwealth, to see where we can develop and deliver better policy outcomes, but where the Commonwealth Government will always have a role in setting priorities and national objectives to social programs such as health and education, as well as the environment and economic programs.

I remind the Prime Minister of the genuine reform discussions on many of these issues that were under way in 1991—initiated by the states because they had had a come-on nod from the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. It was precisely those putative developments in Commonwealth-state relations that Mr Keating crushed in his drive to become Prime Minister. As I said earlier, he used those very issues in his political assassination of the former Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: One would hope that the different levels of government would talk to each other, but that is hardly a new or major development. I hope the Prime Minister means what he says in that third principle. It would mark a return to a semblance of common sense on his part in relation to the issue. Perhaps it is just that reality has only now hit him. To say that it would be a fundamental change in institutional arrangements is quite nonsensical because it is an aspect that should always have been there anyway. As I say, it is one that the Labor government and this Prime Minister in particular have observed more in the breach than in the doing.
The fourth principle is the most important one that I wish to address. As enunciated by the Prime Minister, it is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that while the Commonwealth believes the States should be adequately resourced, it should be taken as understood that the Commonwealth will not be party to any substantial transfer of Commonwealth taxing powers to the States.

So the Prime Minister wants to transfer responsibility for resources to the states with no transfer at all of the financial wherewithal to go with it. It should be remembered that it was Mr Keating as Treasurer in the late 1980s who slashed Commonwealth payments to the states year after year as his main avenue for cutting the budget deficit. He did not have the gumption or the ability to cut own-purpose spending by the Commonwealth; he slashed Commonwealth payments to the states.

PARA.TAB: During the first five or six years of the Hawke Labor government—between 1983-84 and 1989-90—when Mr Keating was the Treasurer, payments to the states as a percentage of gross domestic product fell by over one-third. It fell from 9.8 per cent of GDP to 6.8 per cent, and today the figure is only slightly above that low point. In other words, there has been no effort on the part of the Commonwealth—indeed, efforts have been made to the contrary—to redress the financial problem in a stable, consistent and on-going way.

In his statement this week, the Prime Minister said that he is ruling out of court any prospect for the most fundamental reform required in the area of Commonwealth-state relations, that of the Commonwealth-state financial relationship, giving the states greater ability to and responsibility for raising the revenues they need to meet their own expenditure priorities. That is the most crucial area of Commonwealth-state reform—addressing the so-called vertical fiscal imbalance and providing the states, the main spenders of taxpayer's money, with a reliable and stable revenue source. The states account for around 50 per cent of total government expenditure in Australia yet they raise less than 25 per cent of the revenue. That is a totally unsatisfactory and unstable situation, yet in his speech the other night, the Prime Minister absolutely ruled out any reform to redress it.

The second most crucial area of Commonwealth-state reform is the need for a clear definition of responsibilities—a genuine attempt to eliminate duplication between the states and Commonwealth levels of government. Both problem areas can be directly traced to the on-going centralisation of the federal government. In just about every area of state expenditure and revenue raising one could look at—health, education, housing, child care, land management, industrial relations, training, consumer affairs, and so on—there is an increasing centralisation of powers and responsibilities in the hands of the Commonwealth government and a consequential diminution of the constitutional responsibilities of the states.
The Prime Minister's speech the other night concerns and disappoints me. He concluded by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . within those four principles . . . a new commitment, if you like, a new consensus, a new understanding between the Commonwealth and the States . . .

There is nothing new about these principles. They may appear new to the Prime Minister because he has never understood or cared for our constitutional arrangements for government. He has never understood and cared for the role of anybody other than those under his control. Indeed, never in Australia's history has there been a political leader who has so attempted to trample on the basic institutions of our nation as the current Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating's comments of the other night reek of nothing other than insincerity and hypocrisy. Instead of cooperative federalism, one could describe the Prime Minister's endeavours in the whole area of Commonwealth-state relations as authoritarian centralism. Commitment and consensus, particularly in the area of Commonwealth-state relations, are concepts totally alien to anything that the Prime Minister has ever stood for. I conclude by referring to his speech in October 1991—a major plank in his attempt to get rid of Prime Minister Hawke—when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the end, the Commonwealth has the power of the purse.
His speech this week simply reinforced his commitment to that totally centralist ideology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address two subjects, but my remarks on both will be brief. Firstly, I would like to support the comments made by my colleague Senator Short in relation to what can only be described as the gross hypocrisy of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his statement on the new-new-neo-federalism and his approach to the COAG meeting tomorrow. I will also be addressing the hypocrisy of this government by comparing its treatment of small business and its approach to audits and audit trails under the Corporations Law with the level of accountability that the Prime Minister and, in particular, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) require of people such as Minister Kelly. They are diverse subjects but both could be put under the heading of `Hypocrisy' in the Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short made some very good points about the gross hypocrisy of Prime Minister Keating. The speech to which Senator Short referred was delivered by the same man who, in 1991, oversaw the destruction of what was probably the most genuine attempt at reconciling the federal balance in Australia in the 93 years since Federation—certainly since Malcolm Fraser's attempt at new federalism in the 1970s and 1980s, which was, in many respects, a failure.

Mr Keating's Placido Domingo, off-the-record speech at the National Press Club, in which he made the statements which Senator Short has already put on the record relating to his support of the Whitlamesque centralism of concentrating more power in Canberra and taking away the powers of the state governments, was a crude political attempt inside the Labor caucus to attract the support of centralists such as the Carrs and the Faulkners to vote for him. There is an innate centralist tendency within the Australian Labor Party that distrusts the states and sees that the best way to run Australia is to have power concentrated in Canberra. Many of us are extremely wary of any moves to move power away from the people, away from local communities, to this remote and unusual place of power in Canberra.

There have been a number of changes since Mr Keating became Prime Minister. I suspect that the most rapid centralisation of power has occurred in the past couple of years. I am reminded of a number of specific examples which have occurred in the last 12 months. The Commonwealth's native title legislation that passed through this place in December in one fell swoop became the greatest centralisation of power that has occurred in this nation's history. When the case gets to the High Court we will see whether the Commonwealth has the constitutional power to take over land management in a way that was specifically excluded by the founding fathers when they wrote the constitution.

More recently, on 4 February, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, got an order from the Federal Court to halt the development of a crocodile farm at Broome. That is a very important example of what can, and will, happen under the native title legislation which became law late last year. Minister Tickner took that action under the heritage legislation. As I said in the Senate on 10 February, the action of that minister is very clearly an example of what can occur under the native title legislation.

I will reiterate the following point as many times as I can in the hope that someone may hear me at some stage: even if the Western Australian government under Premier Court decided to acquiesce in the Prime Minister's legislative structures and procedures and set up the sorts of tribunals wanted by the Prime Minister, and subjected people who wanted to make developments in Western Australia, such as a crocodile farm, a tourist development, an iron ore mine or a gold mine a process which takes a minimum of 12 months if there are no problems or objections along the way—bearing in mind that it takes about 70 days to go through it at the moment, so it means shifting a development approval procedure from 70 days out to 12 to 14 months without hiccups or disputes between Aboriginal communities which are trying to decide who should hold the native title—at the end of that period, under native title law, the federal minister still has a period of two months in which he has total discretion to veto the decision of the tribunal.

A tribunal set up under the native title legislation for negotiation, conciliation and agreement between all the parties can say, `Yes, you can go ahead with the development of a crocodile farm at Broome', but at the end of that process the federal minister still has the total right of veto over the tribunal's decision.Those opposite talk about federal and state cooperation, saying, `We will recognise and give good and full faith to the decisions made by your state tribunals on land management', but at the end of the matter the federal minister has the right to intervene. A local traditional Aboriginal owner, recognised for centuries as the traditional owner of a place in Broome, may be successful before the tribunal. But if the Kimberley Land Council comes along—a highly politically motivated organisation, with the ear of the federal minister—and says, `We want you to veto this development because we did not get our way at the tribunal', then the federal minister can intervene.

This is an effective veto over development within the states. It is a massive transfer of power away from the states—and, more importantly, from local citizens and communities—to the federal minister. The Prime Minister has no credentials, he will be travelling to the COAG meeting in Hobart tomorrow and he will not be taken seriously by the premiers who will be meeting him.

One other example is voluntary student unionism. It is a very important issue for people who believe in liberty for Australian citizens. In Western Australia, the entire Court government, including the premier and the education minister, Norman Moore, went to the polls in February last year on a platform which has been our policy for the last 10 years, to ensure that individual students on campus had the right to decide whether or not to join unions. Students are going back to their campuses now—I was at the Curtin University campus last Friday—and are being forced to become members of student unions. Legislation to give effect to its policy is before the Western Australian parliament and will be passed in the next couple of months, depending on how good our manager of government business in the Western Australian parliament is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a good as me.

—Maybe not. That legislation will go through. We have passed through this chamber a bill that ensures that when a state government passes legislation which gives students the freedom to choose whether to join a union, the federal government will take funds away from that state through the higher education grants and penalise it. In the case of Western Australia, it will be a penalty of up to $5 million because that state government is putting into place its election promises and is delivering to Western Australian students, for the first time in history, the freedom to choose whether or not to join a union. This is yet another example of how the federal government can say one thing about giving full faith and credit to state government policies and decisions, but uses its power of the purse to ensure that the state government's policies are hindered and the taxpayers and citizens of that state are penalised because the federal government does not like the state government's policies.

PARA.TAB: So it is a very hypocritical Prime Minister going to this COAG meeting tomorrow. He has now recognised that state governments exist. It has taken 93 years for that recognition to be given, so that is a step forward. But if one reads the Prime Minister's statements, as Senator Short has done, one sees that he has said that the state governments are just a post office for the Commonwealth government. He says they are good because they can provide a few services; they can be handed some money and they can be a post office, a regional office or an outpost for the federal government. That is not our idea of federalism. Our idea of federalism is to ensure that people have control over decisions that affect their lives.

When it comes to environmental matters we want to ensure that people who have dirty rivers and dirty air can have that cleaned up by local and state authorities and not have boffins and politicians in Canberra telling them how to run their lives. It is not about states rights. That is a hackneyed, cliched phrase which has distorted federal-state relations for years. The debate is about democratic rights of individuals. Individuals who do not like their state government or the activities of the politicians who have control of these issues can march up St George's Terrace to Parliament House and demand action from their local politicians. It is very hard for a Western Australian or a Tasmanian to come to Canberra to lobby the environment minister, the Minister for Defence or the Minister for Veterans' Affairs because it costs an absolute fortune.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will know how well you are going from reading your speech.

—Senator Faulkner was over in Perth yesterday, so he knows how far it is. It is a hell of a long way to come to Canberra when one is a bit upset because the Environment Protection Authority over here makes a bad decision. When Barry Carbon was back in Western Australia at least people could travel in a bus to see him or to protest outside his office if they did not like the decisions he made in relation to the environment. Now Barry Carbon is here with the Environment Protection Authority in Canberra it costs people thousands of dollars to come to see him if they do not like his decisions.

PARA.TAB: That is one example of the problems associated with centralising power in Canberra. It is something we oppose. We would like to see a sensible system of government where decisions that can be made affecting day-to-day lives are made as close to the people as possible. That is the sort of system we would like to get to. As Senator Short said, quite properly, that cannot be achieved unless there is a sensible solution to that horrible phrase—vertical fiscal imbalance.

I move to the next subject which will not take long. Again it is to do with hypocrisy. In the last couple of days I have had sent to me by a constituent, who will indeed receive a copy of this speech—it will only cost the Commonwealth one stamp—

TALK.START.PARA: —But won't it go to all your pre-selectors too?
—I never send speeches to pre-selectors.
—I am sure they will be relieved to hear that.

—I have never done that—except for my maiden speech which I sent them and I am sure no-one read it. I am sure Senator Abetz will send out his maiden speech; it will probably be better than mine. It is good to have an ongoing commentary in this speech, but I will get through this quickly without Senator Faulkner's interjections, even though I am enjoying them.

PARA.TAB: The last point I raise relates to a bulletin sent out by the Australian Securities Commission in relation to a new program it is running called record keeping audits. It struck me as being quite hypocritical on the part of the federal government, particularly Michael Lavarch, the Attorney-General, as he has had quite an involvement in handing out some of these cultural and sporting grants. The bulletin about the record keeping audit required by the Australian Taxation Office said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ATO has recently launched the Record Keeping Audit (RKA) program, which highlights the ATO's determination to ensure that small businesses keep adequate records.

Of course that is a very laudable thing, but on behalf of small business people around Australia I say to this federal government that if it is going to spend millions of dollars through the Taxation Office and the Australian Securities Commission sending out thousands of bulletins to small businesses around Australia to `record and explain all transactions and acts engaged', it should ensure that ministers of the federal government over here in Canberra maintain the same level of accountability and record keeping. Of course, I refer to Minister Kelly, if she is still a minister. I have not seen the latest news bulletins; I do not know whether she has gone yet. If a small businessman received that notification from the ASC and the Australian Taxation Office about keeping records—things like journals, sales invoices, loan agreements, minutes and all the records required to explain his business activities—and someone involved in overseeing this record keeping audit were to knock on that small businessman's door, saying, `Where are your records? Where do you keep your records? Where are the records that record and explain all your transactions and acts engaged in?', the taxpayer could say, `I have been watching the television; I have read the Auditor-General's report about the sports grants, the sports rorts affair.' If it is fair enough for a federal minister to keep her records and explanations on a 1 1/2 by 2 1/2 metre whiteboard—which is becoming infamous—and then to rub them out, it would be fair enough for the small businessman to say, `All my records were done on a whiteboard too, and I have not got a photocopier attached to my whiteboard'.

PARA.TAB: Of course, that will not happen because, as is stated in this bulletin:

SPEECH.PARA: It is an offence for a person to lodge documents with the ASC which they know contain false, misleading or inaccurate information and statements. The omission of any information or matter which causes the document to be misleading is also an offence.

The small businessman would be prosecuted by the Australian Securities Commission or the Australian Taxation Office and would suffer damage because there were no records. Of course, that will not happen to this minister because she is a mate of Paul and Annita Keating. She will probably survive this. I think the longer she is there the better, as far as the opposition is concerned. But for the Australian public, the Australian taxpayer and indeed for the credibility of the whole of our nation, the quicker she goes the better.

PARA.TAB: But these small businessmen will suffer penalties ranging from as low as $100 up to thousands of dollars for not keeping adequate records. But if a small businessman said to the tax office auditor or to the Australian Securities Commission investigator, `All my records were on a whiteboard. I am very sorry, I had to use the whiteboard for something else. I had a whiteboard special on today at my lunch shop and I had to use my whiteboard to put the specials up, so the records have gone', he would be punished and severely fined. Of course, if you are a minister handing out grants of $30 million you do not suffer any penalty whatsoever, and Mrs Kelly has suffered no penalty whatsoever for her disgraceful behaviour in this sports rorts affair.

I certainly think that this is a case of hypocrisy when we have organisations such as the Taxation Office and the Australian Securities Commission inflicting masses and masses of regulations requiring small businesses to keep records but a minister of the Crown is not required to keep records to explain her decisions, she just needs a 1 1/2 by a 2 1/2 metre whiteboard. In the last few days we have witnessed two acts of gross hypocrisy, and this government stands condemned on both counts.
